cnd3:1.2: To the one who is undisturbed, the seer of the roots,

cnd3:1.5: Make sacrifices in the world here?

cnd3:2.1: "The one who is not disturbed, the one who sees the root": "Disturbance is
cnd3:2.2: called craving, that is greed, lust, acquiescence, conformity, joy, desire,
cnd3:2.3: obsession, taking, contaminated, disturbance, fraud, (reincarnation) root cause,
cnd3:2.4: (bitter) fertility, tailoring (greed), net, river, bondage, rope, attachment,
cnd3:2.5: accumulation, companionship, desire, intimate interaction, forest, jungle, love,
cnd3:2.6: expectation, relationship, desire for form, desire for sounds, desire for
cnd3:2.7: smells, desire for tastes, desire for touches, desire for acquisition, desire
cnd3:2.8: for wealth, desire for sons, desire for life, the state of desire, hope, prayer,
cnd3:2.9: greedy appearance, possessing greed, inquiring for profit, illegal greed,
cnd3:2.10: improper greed, hope, envy, desire for desire, desire for nothingness, desire
cnd3:2.11: for form, formless thirst, extinguished thirst, form thirst, sound thirst, smell
cnd3:2.12: thirst, taste thirst, touch thirst, dhamma thirst, torrent, harness, binding,
cnd3:2.13: clinging, obstacles, covering, defilements, potential trends of troubles,
cnd3:2.14: entanglement, vines, stinginess, suffering roots, causes of suffering,
cnd3:2.15: occurrence of suffering, magical nets, magical hooks, magical food, the realm of
cnd3:2.16: the devil, the residence of the devil, the state of the devil, the bondage of
cnd3:2.17: the devil, the river of thirst, the net of thirst, the rope of thirst, the sea
cnd3:2.18: of thirst, craving, greed, and the root of unwholesomeness. For the Buddhas and
cnd3:2.19: the Blessed One, that disturbance is cut off, the root has been cut off, just
cnd3:2.20: like a palm tree without roots, becoming non-existent, a non-living thing for
cnd3:2.21: the future, so the Buddha is the undisturbed. In the state of that disturbance
cnd3:2.22: being disconnection, the Blessed One does not waver; does not shake when he does
cnd3:2.23: not get it (obtain something); does not shake when he has reputation; does not
cnd3:2.24: shake when he has no reputation; does not shake with praise; does not shake with
cnd3:2.25: reprimand; does not shake at times; does not shake, does not move, does not
cnd3:2.26: tremble. "The one who sees the root," the Blessed One sees the roots, is the
cnd3:2.27: seer of the cause, seer of the origin, seer of the abiding (origin), seer of the
cnd3:2.28: nutriment, seer of the object, seer of the condition, seer of the set of views.
cnd3:3.1: There are three unwholesome roots: the unwholesome root of greed, of aversion,
cnd3:4.1: This was said by the Blessed One: Bhikkhus! There are causes and conditions for
cnd3:4.2: these three kamma gatherings; which three are there? Greed is the cause and
cnd3:4.3: condition of kamma, hatred is the cause and condition of kamma, and delusion is
cnd3:4.4: the cause and condition of kamma. Bhikkhus! It's not because of greed, hatred,
cnd3:4.5: or delusion that the heavens are known, people are known, or any good interests
cnd3:4.6: are known, bhikkhus! But because of greed, hatred, and delusion, the hell world
cnd3:4.7: is known, the animal world is known, the hungry ghost world is known, or any
cnd3:4.8: other evil interest [AN.6.39]; individuals in hell, the animal world, and the
cnd3:4.9: hungry ghost world are known. These three unwholesome roots, the Blessed One
cnd3:4.10: knows and sees, and so so Blessed One is the seer of the root... (omitted).
cnd3:4.11: There are three good roots: the good root of no greed, of no hatred, and of no
cnd3:5.1: This was said by the Blessed One: Bhikkhus! There are these three... (omitted)
cnd3:5.2: bhikkhus! It's not that the hell of no greed, no hatred, no delusion is known,
cnd3:5.3: the animal world is known, the hungry ghost world is known, or any evil
cnd3:5.4: interests are known, bhikkhus! But without greed, without hatred, without
cnd3:5.5: delusion, heaven is known, man is known, or any good interest: those in heaven
cnd3:5.6: and the world arise and are known. The Blessed One knows and sees the three good
cnd3:5.7: roots, so the Blessed One is the seer of the root....
cnd3:6.1: This was said by the Blessed One: Bhikkhus! Any unwholesome Dhamma, unwholesome
cnd3:6.2: division, unwholesome faction [AN.1.56], all that is rooted in ignorance,
cnd3:6.3: converged in ignorance, and eradicated with ignorance, all that will be
cnd3:6.4: eradicated. [SN.20.1] The Blessed One knows and sees....
cnd3:7.1: This was said by the Blessed One: Bhikkhus! Any good dhamma, good division, and
cnd3:7.2: good faction [AN.1.57], rooted in non-relaxation, and unbridled as reunion, this
cnd3:7.3: is said to be the number one among those dhammas. [SN.45.139] The Blessed One
cnd3:8.1: Or, the Blessed One knows and sees: Ignorance is the root of action, action is
cnd3:8.2: the root of consciousness, consciousness is the root of name and form, name and
cnd3:8.3: form are the roots of six sense bases, the six sense bases are the roots of
cnd3:8.4: contact, contact is the root of sensation, sensation is the root of craving,
cnd3:8.5: craving is the root of clinging, clinging the root of becoming, becoming is the
cnd3:8.6: root of birth, and birth is the root of old age (and death). The Blessed One
cnd3:9.1: Or, the Blessed One knows and sees: The eye is the root of eye disease, the ear
cnd3:9.2: is the root of ear disease, the nose..., the tongue..., the body..., and the
cnd3:9.3: mind is the root of suffering. The Blessed One knows and sees....
cnd3:10.1: "[Like this Venerable Punṇạka]": "Like this," the continuation of the sentences,
cnd3:10.2: the connection of the words, the completion of the sentences, the combination of
cnd3:10.3: words, this is the order of the sentence, which is "like this." "Venerable,"
cnd3:10.4: this is a synonym of love, respect, and obedience. "Punṇạka," the name, title,
cnd3:10.5: security of the Brāhmaṇa, title, word, phrase.
cnd3:11.1: "The ones in need come with questions": I come with questions as needed, I come
cnd3:11.2: if I want to ask questions, I come if I want to hear questions, the needy come
cnd3:11.3: with questions. Or, the inquirers of the question have the need, the one who
cnd3:11.4: wants to ask the question, the one who wants to hear, the needy (will) come,
cnd3:11.5: approach, visit. Or, when you have a question, you can and you have enough
cnd3:11.6: reason to tell and answer the question I asked, "Please bear this burden."
cnd3:12.1: "People who rely, rishis": Rely on, stick to, enter, or turn their hearts toward
cnd3:12.2: something. "Rishis," who are named immortals, and whichever bhikkhus become
cnd3:13.1: "Khattiyas, Brāhmaṇas, to the gods": "Khattiyas," everything that is born of
cnd3:13.2: khattiya. "Brāhmaṇas," whoever calls others gentlemen. "To the gods," other
cnd3:13.3: ascetics (ājīvakā) to their god (devatā), Jains to their god, matted-hair
cnd3:13.4: ascetics to their god, wandering mendicants to their god, the exiled god..., the
cnd3:13.5: elephant god..., horse god, bull god, dog god, crow god, Vishnu god, the power
cnd3:13.6: of the power ring-keeper, the man of the virtuous ring, the jewel of the
cnd3:13.7: virtuous ring, the fire..., the dragon .., the golden-winged..., Yakkha, Asura,
cnd3:13.8: Gandhabba, the great king god of the guard (heaven), the moon god, sun god,
cnd3:13.9: Indā, Brahma.... Those who are worthy of offering to them are their gods.
cnd3:14.1: "There are many sacrifices in the world": "Sacrifice" is called a donation:
cnd3:14.2: clothing, food, shelter, necessities for patients, medical necessities, food,
cnd3:14.3: drink, cloth, transportation, garlands, spices, oils, bed, house, lamps and
cnd3:14.4: candles. "As a sacrifice," wherever they seek, pursue, and beg for clothing,
cnd3:14.5: food (omitted) ...are used as sacrifices; wherever they prepare clothing, food
cnd3:14.6: ...are also used as sacrifices; wherever they give, provide, and donate
cnd3:14.7: clothing, food ...also make sacrifices. "Many," these sacrifices are many, or
cnd3:14.8: the priests of these sacrifices are many, or there are many worthy providers.
cnd3:14.9: How are there sacrifices many? The clothes, food ...belong to many, so these
cnd3:15.1: How is it that there are many priests of these sacrifices? There are many
cnd3:15.2: priests of these sacrifices: khattiya, Brāhmaṇa, vessa, sudda, laymen, bhikkhus,
cnd3:15.3: heavens, and people, so there are many priests of these sacrifices.
cnd3:16.1: How is or are there many worthwhile providers? There are many Samaṇas,
cnd3:16.2: Brāhmaṇas, beggars, travelers, wanderers, and beggars, so there are many worthy
cnd3:16.3: of offering. "Here is in the world," in the human world.
cnd3:17.1: "Blessed One, I ask you, please tell me": "Asking," there are three types of
cnd3:17.2: inquiry: inquiry about the explanation of the unseen, inquiry about the
cnd3:17.3: confluence of the seen, and inquiry about the cutting off of doubt.
cnd3:18.1: What is an inquiry about the unseen? The unknown, unseen, unmeasured, unjudged,
cnd3:18.2: unclear characteristic, for the purpose of his wisdom, seeing, measuring,
cnd3:18.3: judging, making clear, he asked a question.
cnd3:19.1: What is an inquiry about the confluence of the seen? A characteristic that was
cnd3:19.2: known, seen, measured, judged, clear, and understood. He asked questions for the
cnd3:19.3: purpose of confluence with other wise men.
cnd3:20.1: What is an inquiry for the cutting off of doubt? A leap-into skeptic, jump-in
cnd3:20.2: doubter, and born doubter: "Is that so? Isn't it true? What is it then? How is
cnd3:20.3: it?" He asks questions for the purpose of severance of doubt.
cnd3:21.1: The next three types of inquiry: human inquiry, non-human inquiry, and inquiry
cnd3:22.1: What is a human inquiry? People asked questions after they went to see the
cnd3:22.2: Buddha, the Blessed One: bhikkhus, upāsakas, upāsikās, kings, khattiya,
cnd3:22.3: Brāhmaṇas, vessas, suddas, lay people, monastics.
cnd3:23.1: What is an inhuman inquiry? The non-people asked questions after they went to
cnd3:23.2: see the Buddha, Blessed One: the dragons, golden-winged birds, Yakkha, Asuras,
cnd3:24.1: What is the inquiry of the created? All the physical bodies and limbs of the
cnd3:24.2: Blessed One's mind-made forms draw near and ask questions after seeing the
cnd3:24.3: Blessed One, and the Blessed One answers him.
cnd3:25.1: The next three types of inquiry: inquiry for one's own benefit, inquiry for the
cnd3:25.2: benefit of others, and inquiry for the benefit of both. The next three:
cnd3:25.3: inquiries about current interests, inquiries about future interests, and
cnd3:25.4: inquiries about the highest interests. The next three: inquiry for the benefit
cnd3:25.5: of no faults, inquiry for the benefit of no pollution, and inquiry for the pure
cnd3:25.6: benefit. The next three: (about) past queries, future queries, and current
cnd3:25.7: queries. The next three: (about) inquiries within oneself, inquiries outside
cnd3:25.8: oneself, and inquiries within and outside oneself. The next three: (about) good
cnd3:25.9: merit, demerit, and the undesignated (abyākatapucchā) The next three: (about)
cnd3:25.10: masses, relics, and institutions. The next three: about mindfulness, about
cnd3:25.11: diligence, about spiritual content. The next three: about the root, the
cnd3:25.12: strength, and the enlightenment. The next three: about the Path, the Fruit, and
cnd3:26.1: "I ask you," I ask of you; I beg you; please make me clear; please tell me.
cnd3:26.2: "Blessed One" is is synonymous with respect. In addition, the "greed breaker" is
cnd3:26.3: the Blessed One; the "sickness destroyer" is the Blessed One; "the one who has
cnd3:26.4: destroyed conceit" is the Blessed One; "the one who has destroyed the thorns" is
cnd3:26.5: the Blessed One; "the one who has destroyed the pollutants" is Blessed One; "the
cnd3:26.6: one who has ended" is the Blessed One; "the one who has practiced the body, the
cnd3:26.7: precepts, the mind, and the wisdom" is the Blessed One; or "the Blessed One is
cnd3:26.8: close to the woods, wild forests, and border dwellings (sitting place), where
cnd3:26.9: speaking is lessened, it is quiet, away from the human atmosphere, alone, and
cnd3:26.10: suitable for sitting alone" is the Blessed One; or "the Blessed One is the one
cnd3:26.11: who divides clothes, food, shelter, the needs of patients, and medical
cnd3:26.12: necessities"; or "the Blessed One is the one who has the taste of righteousness,
cnd3:26.13: the taste of Dhamma, the taste of liberation, the increased precepts, the mind,
cnd3:26.14: and the wisdom"; or "the Blessed One is the four types of jhāna, the four
cnd3:26.15: immeasurables, the four formlessness, etc., the one who divides is the Blessed
cnd3:26.16: One"; or the Blessed One is the one who has the eighth liberation, the eight
cnd3:26.17: victories, the ninth dwelling place, etc.; or the Blessed One is the practice of
cnd3:26.18: ten thoughts, (ten) abidings, the one who (observes) the in and out of breath;
cnd3:26.19: the one who is purely divided is the Blessed One; or the Blessed One divides the
cnd3:26.20: four mindfulness, the four righteousness, the four divine bases (iddhipāda), the
cnd3:26.21: five faculties, the five powers, the seven enlightenment factors, and the eight
cnd3:26.22: branches of the holy path; or the Blessed One is ten Tathāgata, four
cnd3:26.23: fearlessness, four unobstructed solutions, six supernatural powers and the six
cnd3:26.24: enlightenment methods. "Blessed One," this name is not given by the mother; not
cnd3:26.25: given by the father; not given by brothers; not given by sisters; not given by
cnd3:26.26: friends; not given by relatives; not given by Samaṇas or Brāhmaṇas; not given by
cnd3:26.27: heaven; it is ultimate liberation; the establishment (of the pseudonym) for the
cnd3:26.28: acquisition and testimony of the Buddha, the Blessed One, under the Bodhi tree,
cnd3:26.29: and all knowledge and wisdom, that is, the Blessed One.
cnd3:27.1: "Please tell me this," please say, please explain, please teach,
cnd3:27.2: please inform, please build, please uncover, please analyze, please clarify.
cnd3:28.2: Any of these rishis, people, khattiyas, and Brāhmaṇas,
cnd3:28.3: Have made many sacrifices here in the world to the gods,
cnd3:28.4: Looking forward to such a state of existence;
cnd3:28.5: Bound to their aging, they made sacrifices.
cnd3:28.7: Any of these rishis, people, khattiyas, and Brāhmaṇas,

cnd3:30.1: "Looking forward to the state of (reincarnation)": "Looking forward," looking
cnd3:30.2: forward to the acquisition of form, looking forward to the acquisition of sound,
cnd3:30.3: (omitted)...of smell, ...of taste, ...of touch, ...of a son, ...of a wife,
cnd3:30.4: ...property, fame, sovereignty, of individuals in the khattiya home with the

cnd3:30.6: the homes of the homeowners with the Great Hall, individuals in the four kings

cnd3:30.8: wisdom, in optimism, in the heavens of others, in the Brahma heavens, the
cnd3:30.9: individual gains, wanting, accepting, aspiring, eagerly looking forward, and
cnd3:31.1: "Looking forward to such a state of reincarnation": Looking forward to the
cnd3:31.2: rebirth of the individual here; I look forward to the rebirth of the individual
cnd3:31.3: in the khattiya home with the Great Hall... (omitted) ...wanting, receiving,
cnd3:31.4: aspiring, eagerly looking forward, and praying.
cnd3:32.1: "They are bound to aging, hence they make sacrifices": Those who are bound to
cnd3:32.2: aging, those who are bound to sickness, to death, to sorrow grief, suffering,
cnd3:32.3: and despair. When they are dependent on birth, they are dependent on aging; when
cnd3:32.4: they are dependent on aging, they are dependent on sickness; ...(omitted) on
cnd3:32.5: sickness...(omitted) death; on death, sorrow, suffering, and despair; on
cnd3:32.6: interest, rebirth; on rebirth, reincarnation; when they are dependent on
cnd3:32.7: reincarnation, then they are stuck, trapped, infected; those who are moving, and
cnd3:32.8: those whose hearts are turned towards (it).
cnd3:33.2: Any of these rishis, people, khattiyas, and Brāhmaṇas,
cnd3:33.3: Making many sacrifices to the gods in the world, Blessed One,
cnd3:33.4: Not letting go on the road of sacrifice,
cnd3:33.5: Are there those who have crossed through birth and aging, dear sir?
cnd3:33.6: Blessed One, I ask you, please tell me this.

cnd3:35.1: "Master! Is it true that there are those who do not let go on the road of
cnd3:35.2: sacrifice": "Is it true," question of doubt, question of confusion, question of
cnd3:35.3: confusion, a rhetorical question, ironic question. "Those" are priests of
cnd3:35.4: sacrifices. "Blessed One," .... "Blessed One! Are there really those..." "Those
cnd3:35.5: who do not let go on the road of sacrifice," the sacrifice is called the
cnd3:35.6: sacrifice road, such as the holy road is the holy road; the heaven is the sky
cnd3:35.7: road; the scripture road is the scripture road; similarly, the sacrifice is
cnd3:35.8: called the sacrifice road. "Do not let go," those who do not let go on the road
cnd3:35.9: of sacrifice are respectful actors, constant actors, non-stop actors, those who
cnd3:35.10: are not stuck in the habit, those who do not neglect their desires, those who
cnd3:35.11: have the character, those who have more, and those who are vigilant..
cnd3:36.1: The one who targets that, the one who strives, the one who overcomes, the one
cnd3:36.2: who increases, they are those who do not let go on the road of sacrifice:
cnd3:36.3: whoever they seek, pursue, and beg, the clothing, food...(omitted), they are
cnd3:36.4: respectful actors...(omitted) to those who increase, then they are those who do
cnd3:36.5: not let go on the road of sacrifices; whoever prepares clothing, food..., they
cnd3:36.6: are respectful actors.... To those who increase it, they are also those who do
cnd3:36.7: not let go on the road of sacrifice; wherever they give, provide, and donate
cnd3:36.8: clothing, food..., they are respectful actors.... To those who increase, then
cnd3:36.9: they are also those who do not let go on the road of sacrifice.
cnd3:37.1: "Living through birth and aging, dear sir": Aging and death, they pass,
cnd3:37.2: transcend, and overcome. "Dear Sir," this is a synonym for love, respect,
cnd3:38.1: "Master, I ask you, please tell me this": "I ask you," I beg you; make it clear
cnd3:38.2: to me; "Please tell me," tell me. "Blessed One," a respectful synonym....
cnd3:39.2: They expect, appreciate, pray, and offer, for gain.
cnd3:39.3: They are dedicated confessors and greedy people.
cnd3:39.4: I say that they have not survived birth and aging.

cnd3:39.12: I say that they have not survived birth and aging.
cnd3:39.14: They expect, appreciate, pray, and offer, for gain.
cnd3:39.15: They are dedicated confessors and greedy people.
cnd3:39.16: I say that they have not survived birth and aging.
cnd3:40.1: "They expect, appreciate, pray, and offer": "They expect," They expect the
cnd3:40.2: acquisition of form, they expect the acquisition of sound, ...smell, taste,
cnd3:41.1: "They appreciate," They appreciate the sacrifice, or they appreciate the result,
cnd3:41.2: or they appreciate the one who should be offered. How do they appreciate
cnd3:41.3: sacrifices? What is done is pure, what is done is satisfactory, ...wonderful,
cnd3:41.4: ...timely, appropriate, is after selection (review), is not faulty. Giving is
cnd3:41.5: continuous (usual), giving is pure and convincing. They admire and praise, so
cnd3:41.6: they appreciate sacrifices in this way.
cnd3:42.1: How do they appreciate the results? With causes like these (sacrifices) they
cnd3:42.2: expect individual gains in the Brahma Heaven. They admire, praise, and
cnd3:42.3: appreciate the result in this way.
cnd3:43.1: How do they appreciate those who should be supported? Those who should be
cnd3:43.2: supported are those with sufficient birth (blood line), those with sufficient
cnd3:43.3: surnames (family), readers, mantra holders, the vocabulary, rituals, phonology
cnd3:43.4: and etymology of the Three Vedas, and ancient history is the fifth proficiency.
cnd3:43.5: Those who know well, those who know the sacred sentences, those who understand
cnd3:43.6: grammar, the one who is not deficient in the worldly relationship with a man,
cnd3:43.7: the one who is free from greed or for the sake of greed, or the one who is an
cnd3:43.8: outsider for the sake of aversion, the ignorant or those who participate in the
cnd3:43.9: sake of ignorance, those who believe in sufficiency in precepts, those who have
cnd3:43.10: prohibitions, those who have sufficient wisdom, those who have sufficient
cnd3:43.11: liberation, those who have sufficient views. They admire, appreciate
cnd3:44.1: "They pray," They prayed for the acquisition of form, they prayed for the
cnd3:44.2: acquisition of sound, ...(omitted). They look forward to, appreciate, and pray.
cnd3:44.3: "They offer," they give, sacrifice, give away clothes, food ...(omitted).
cnd3:45.1: "They pray for their desire for profit": They pray for the acquisition of form,
cnd3:46.1: "They are dedicated confessors (devotees to sacrifice), greedy, I said they have
cnd3:46.2: not survived birth and aging." "They" are called priests of sacrifices. "The
cnd3:46.3: dedication of the offering," the harness of devotion, the strong harness, the
cnd3:46.4: man of character, the more, the heavier, the person who is the object of it,
cnd3:46.5: toward the effort, toward the inclination, toward the overcomer, toward the
cnd3:46.6: increaser. "A greedy person," whoever has desire, greed, joy, thirst, love,
cnd3:46.7: passion, and fascination. It is called the greed of existence. The greed of the
cnd3:46.8: existence is bound, obsessed, tainted, attached, fixed, obstructed.
cnd3:47.1: "I said they have not survived 'birth and aging,'" Those who are dedicated to
cnd3:47.2: offering sacrifices, the greedy, they have not survived, surpassed, passed, or
cnd3:47.3: overcome birth, aging, and death. Birth, aging, and death are not separated, not
cnd3:47.4: left, not crossed, not overcome, they turn in the cycle of birth, aging, and
cnd3:47.5: death; of rebirth, accompanied by birth, followed by aging, conquered by
cnd3:47.6: disease, and tortured by death; there is no refuge. I say, I explain, I teach, I
cnd3:47.7: inform, I build, I uncover, I analyze, I clarify.
cnd3:48.2: If those dedicated to offering sacrifices do not,
cnd3:48.3: Through their sacrifices, live through birth and aging, dear sir!
cnd3:48.4: In that case, who lives through birth and aging
cnd3:48.5: In the world of heaven and man, dear sir?
cnd3:48.6: Blessed One, I ask you, please tell me this.

cnd3:48.9: Through their sacrifices, live through birth and aging, dear sir!
cnd3:48.10: In that case, who lives through birth and aging
cnd3:48.11: In the world of heaven and man, dear sir?
cnd3:48.12: Blessed One, I ask you, please tell me this.

cnd3:48.16: In that case, who lives through birth and aging

cnd3:48.34: In that case, who lives through birth and aging

cnd3:49.1: "If those dedicated to offering sacrifices have not survived": The priests of
cnd3:49.2: sacrifices, dedicated sacrificers, and greedy people, birth and old age, they
cnd3:49.3: have not survived, surpassed, and passed through death, they did not cross, did
cnd3:49.4: not overcome; birth, aging, death were not separated, not left, not crossed;
cnd3:49.5: they reverted in birth, aging, and death, they revolved in the cycle of
cnd3:50.1: "[Like this]": "Like this," the continuation of the sentence....
cnd3:51.1: "By sacrifice ...birth and aging, dear sir ": "Sacrifices," with many
cnd3:51.2: sacrifices, with various types of sacrifices. "Dear sir," ....
cnd3:52.1: "In that case, who in the world of heaven and man, through birth and aging, dear
cnd3:52.2: sir": And who is in this world including heaven, demons, and Brāhmaṇa; including
cnd3:52.3: the generations of Samaṇas, Brāhmaṇas, heaven and man; who has passed, overcome,
cnd3:53.1: "Master, I ask you, please tell me this": "I ask you," ....
cnd3:54.2: After considering the upper and lower in the world,
cnd3:54.3: Without anywhere wavering in the world,
cnd3:54.4: Quiet, without smoke, without worries, without desires,
cnd3:54.5: I say he has lived through birth and aging.

cnd3:55.1: "Considering the upper and lower in the world": After consideration, it is
cnd3:55.2: called wisdom, understanding, simple selection, investigation, discernment,
cnd3:55.3: recognition, discrimination, close observation, inspection, learned virtuous
cnd3:55.4: wisdom, proficiency, cleverness, study, reflection, review, contemplation,
cnd3:55.5: examination, general comprehensive wisdom, vipassanā, right knowledge, stabbing
cnd3:55.6: rod, wisdom root, wisdom sword, wisdom palace, wisdom brightness, wisdom light,
cnd3:55.7: no delusion, choice of dhamma, right view. "Upper and lower," the lower part is
cnd3:55.8: called one's own individual, and the upper part is called other individuals; the
cnd3:55.9: lower part is called one's own physical perception, thinking, and consciousness;
cnd3:55.10: the upper part is called other people's physical consciousness; the upper is
cnd3:55.11: called the six outer places; the lower is called the world of humans, the upper
cnd3:55.12: is called the world of heaven; the lower is called the world of desire, the
cnd3:55.13: upper is called the realm of material, and the world of formlessness; the lower
cnd3:55.14: is called the world of desire and material, the world is called the formless
cnd3:55.15: world. "Considering the upper and lower in the world": Considering the upper and
cnd3:55.16: lower as impermanent, suffering, illness, sick... (omitted) after leaving, after
cnd3:55.17: he considers, knows, understands, weighs, judges, after separation, after
cnd3:56.1: "[The Blessed One: 'Punṇạka']": "Punṇạka," the Blessed One calls that Brāhmaṇa
cnd3:57.1: "For him, there is no wavering in the world": "For him," the Arahant, the one
cnd3:57.2: who has exhausted troubles. "Wavering," of craving, of seeing, of conceit, of
cnd3:57.3: pollution, the shaking of desire; for him, they do not exist, are not known, are
cnd3:57.4: not found, they have been cut off, calmed down, stopped, unable to arise, burned
cnd3:57.5: by the fire of wisdom. "Anywhere," no matter where, inside or outside or inside
cnd3:58.1: "Silent, smokeless, without distress, without desire, I say that he has survived
cnd3:58.2: 'birth and aging'": "Silent," the state of silenced greed, ...aversion,
cnd3:58.3: ...ignorance, anger, resentment, hiding of evil, all unwholesome actions;
cnd3:58.4: silent, calmed down, extinguished, cooled, departed, and ceased. "Smokeless,"
cnd3:58.5: the evil deeds of the body are smokeless, destroyed, dried up, withered, and
cnd3:58.6: eliminated; evil deeds of speech... (omitted); of the mind; greed; anger;
cnd3:58.7: ignorance; resentment; of hiding evil; of envy; of stinginess; of cunning;
cnd3:58.8: passion; sloth; torpor; idleness; all pollution; all evils; all afflictions; all
cnd3:58.9: scorching heat (torment); all bad deeds are smokeless, destroyed, withered, have
cnd3:58.10: been wiped out. Or, anger is called smoke:
cnd3:59.2: Anger is your smoke, and lies are your grey (ashes).
cnd3:59.3: The tongue is the ladle for sacrifice, the heart is the furnace for sacrifice,
cnd3:59.4: And the self that is well-tuned is the fire of men."
cnd3:60.1: Or, anger is aroused in ten forms: "He has been unfavorable to me," [AN.9.29]
cnd3:60.2: anger is aroused; "he is unfavorable to me," anger is aroused; "he will be
cnd3:60.3: unfavorable to me," ...(omitted); "he has been against what I love and desire to
cnd3:60.4: do," "he is against what I love and desire to do," "he will be...," "he has been
cnd3:60.5: in favor of what I do not love and do not desire to do," "he is in favor," "he
cnd3:60.6: will be in favor," anger is aroused; or anger is aroused in an unreasonable
cnd3:60.7: place. Any type of anger, hostility, hatred, aversion, evil, heart aversion,
cnd3:60.8: arrogance, aggression, rage, displeasure: this is called anger.
cnd3:61.1: In addition, the extreme and small states of anger should be perceived:
cnd3:61.2: sometimes anger is only to the degree of turbidity, but not as much as frowning;
cnd3:61.3: sometimes anger is just to the degree of, but not as much as gritting teeth;
cnd3:61.4: sometimes ...gritted teeth, but not ...verbal abuse; sometimes verbal abuse, but
cnd3:61.5: not looking around for a weapon; sometimes looking for a weapon but not enough
cnd3:61.6: to take up a weapon; sometimes enough to acquire the weapon, but not enough to
cnd3:61.7: pull out the rod; sometimes pulling out the rod, but not striking the rod;
cnd3:61.8: sometimes striking a blow, but not fracturing; sometimes fracturing, but not
cnd3:61.9: enough to rupture; sometimes rupturing, but not pulling limbs; sometimes pulling
cnd3:61.10: limbs apart, but not enough to kill; sometimes enough to kill, but not not
cnd3:61.11: enough to abandon himself. When the angry person kills himself after killing
cnd3:61.12: others, this is such that the anger reaches the increase, and the further
cnd3:61.13: reaches the increase. For him whose anger is cut off, calmed down..., he is
cnd3:62.1: The state where anger has been cut off is smokeless; the state where anger has
cnd3:62.2: been known is smokeless; anger is smokeless because it has been known; anger
cnd3:62.3: that has been severed is smokeless. "No distress," greed is distress, anger is
cnd3:62.4: distress, ignorance is distress, ...(omitted), all unwholesome deeds are
cnd3:62.5: distress. For him, who has cut off..., he is the who has with no distress.
cnd3:63.1: "No desire," desire is called craving, that is greed, lust... (omitted),
cnd3:63.2: unwholesome roots. For him who this desire is cut off..., he is called the one
cnd3:63.3: who has no desire. "Birth": Among all living beings, of each type of birth,
cnd3:63.4: entry into (the womb), manifestation of various aggregates, and attainment of
cnd3:63.5: each type of sentient being. "Aging": Among all living beings, about the aging,
cnd3:63.6: tooth loss, hair whitening, wrinkles, declining life span, and degeneration of
cnd3:63.7: the roots of each type of living beings. "For those who are silent, smokeless,
cnd3:63.8: without distress, and without desire, I say that he has survived 'birth and
cnd3:63.9: aging'": Anyone who is silent, smokeless, without distress, and without desire;
cnd3:63.10: birth, aging, and dying have been overcome, transcended, passed, crossed; I say,
cnd3:63.11: I explain, I teach, I inform, I build, I uncover, I parse, I clarify.
